title: Mum at breaking point trying to find 24-hour care for daughter with heart failure
text:

A desperate mum says she is at breaking point trying to find 24-hour care for her daughter with heart failure.

Gaby Irvine, five, needs round-the-clock care to ensure she is able to breathe and has already had three open heart surgeries in her short life.

Currently, when Gaby's carers are on annual leave or unable to stay with her if they are ill, mum Lynsey must stay awake all night to ensure her daughter remains alive.

Lynsey also works as Gaby’s classroom assistant at Millisle Primary School near their home in Co Down, Northern Ireland, and works as her full-time carer during the day.

By the end of this week she will have had no help to look after her daughter’s night-time needs for five days out of eight, and without the sleep she needs, the 30-year-old mum-of-three says she is at breaking point, reports Belfast Live.

Lynsey explained: “Gaby has brilliant carers but they need annual leave and they can get sick too and Gaby cannot afford to be with people who are sick because her defences are so low.

“So we are facing five out of eight days without any help and that means I literally have to stay awake 24 hours to make sure Gaby is OK.

“At night she sleeps in a bed in the living room and she is monitored around the clock. She can need suctioned or ventilated and she can need oxygen too. Gaby cannot sleep on her own without someone to watch her.

“At the age of five she has already had three open heart surgeries and life is hard for her. But she never complains although she is starting to notice that other kids are not ventilated like her. So it’s heartbreaking to try to explain what’s going on.

“We were offered 110 hours of care for her every week but I said we would mange with 70 but now I’ve been told that when Gaby’s carers, who we love, are on annual leave or are sick, we will have no one to cover for them.

“That leaves us in a pretty impossible situation. I’m really not someone to complain about getting help but perhaps that’s why we’re in this position and now we’re at breaking point.

“We have just spent the weekend doing night shifts so that means staying awake to watch Gaby sleep, doing her medicines, monitoring her oxygen levels, all the things she needs done to live her life as normally as possible.

“We’ve been told the South Eastern Care Trust cannot cover the sick leave and we also have no cover three nights of this coming week because there is no cover for annual leave.

“That’s five out of eight nights uncovered.

“I have been told that the Trust has advised not to cover annual leave or sick leave in Gaby’s package and then I was told everyone is in the same boat.

“If I could be my daughter’s classroom assistant in school and her full-time carer day and night at home, and cover any sick or annual leave for night time hours, I would. But I physically cannot stay awake 24 hours a day nor can her daddy David who works full-time to support our family.

“I’m exhausted and I feel angry and I feel like we are being picked out for saying nothing and not making a fuss.

“My little girl deserves so much more and so do her brothers, they all deserve a mummy who is not too tired to play or take them out without dreading it because of the stress I am under.

“And anyone that knows me knows that I’m normally quiet and I do all I can try to make people’s lives easier, but my children are suffering here and I need the help that was promised to us as a family.”

A spokesperson for the South Eastern Trust said: “The lead nurse is going to meet mum at 1pm tomorrow to discuss this case further. In relation to queries below -

“The Children's Community Nursing Team works in partnership with all parents to ensure care packages are adequately covered, either by the parents or other staff.

“Parents are informed of annual leave a number of weeks in advance and arrangements agreed for the cover, parents often wish to cover this themselves.

“Sick leave is more difficult to be covered at short notice, but will be covered as soon as possible in the event of a prolonged period of sickness, working in partnership with the parents.

There is no moratorium on cover within care packages. The Trust will continue to work directly with mum to agree the support package required.

"All community support packages are individualised and agreed with each user. The Trust has been in contact with the family today and will continue until the matter is resolved.”
description: Gaby Irvine, five, needs round-the-clock care to ensure she is able to breathe and has already had three open heart surgeries in her short life
